RECORD.TEXT: FIH 7111426 11/19/1994 12:00:00 AM Discharge Summary Unsigned DIS Unsigned ADMISSION DATE : 11/19/94 DISCHARGE DATE : 11/28/94 ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS : HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : The patient developed hematemesis November 15th and was intubated for respiratory distress . He was transferred to the Valtawnprinceel Community Memorial Hospital for endoscopy and esophagoscopy on the 16th of November which showed a 2 cm linear tear of the esophagus at 30 to 32 cm . The patient 's hematocrit was stable and he was given no further intervention . The patient attempted a gastrografin swallow on the 21st , but was unable to cooperate with probable aspiration . The patient also had been receiving generous intravenous hydration during the period for which he was NPO for his esophageal tear and intravenous Lasix for a question of pulmonary congestion . On the morning of the 22nd the patient developed tachypnea with a chest X-ray showing a question of congestive heart failure . A medical consult was obtained at the Valtawnprinceel Community Memorial Hospital . The patient was given intravenous Lasix . A arterial blood gases on 100 percent face mask showed an oxygen of 205 , CO2 57 and PH 7.3 . An electrocardiogram showed ST depressions in V2 through V4 which improved with sublingual and intravenous nitroglycerin . The patient was transferred to the Coronary Care Unit for management of his congestive heart failure , ischemia and probable aspiration pneumonia . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : 1. coronary artery disease . 2. non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus , 4. history of cholecystectomy . The patient 's medications at home were Micronase , Isordil and aspirin . 8. SOCIAL HISTORY : He is a former alcoholic , but without any alcohol in 30 years prior to admission . He is legally blind . On physical examination he is a tachypneic white male on 40 percent face mask with oxygen saturations 98 percent . Blood pressure 150/60 , heart rate 90 's , respirations 22 . His oropharynx was clear . He had no gag . He did count fingers in both eyes at one foot . He had 2+ carotids on time without bruits . His heart rate was regular rate and rhythm . He had diffuse rhonchi and upper airway noises . His abdomen was benign . He had guaiac positive brown stool with a normal prostate . His neurological examination was remarkable for a mildly encephalopathic male . He was oriented times two . He moved extremities times four . His reflexes were 2+ and symmetric . His toes were down going . LABORATORY DATA : Four liter arterial blood gas of 71/43/7.45 , ionized calcium 1.03 , normal electrolytes , BUN and creatinine 16/1.4 , glucose 246 , calc , mag and phos normal , albumin 2.2 , LDH 227 , liver function tests normal , white count 10.6 , hematocrit 32 which was 31 on the 19th and 38 on the 16th , prothrombin time 9.9 , partial thromboplastin time 26 . A sputum gram stain showed moderate polys with few gram negative rods . A chest X-ray showed bilateral opacities in the bases with increased interstitial markings . An electrocardiogram on admission to the CCU showed normal sinus , 90 beats per minute , with a normal axis , normal intervals , an old inferior myocardial infarction and up sloping ST depressions with V2 to V4 with increased rate . These improved with decreased rate . HOSPITAL COURSE : He was also placed on intravenous nitroglycerin , oxygen and aspirin for his coronary ischemia . No heparin was given because of his esophageal laceration . No beta blocker was given because of his history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease . The patient remained stable in the Coronary Care Unit and was transferred to the floor on the 23rd on aspirin , Carafate , intravenous Haldol , nebs , Unasyn , NPH with CZI sliding coverage , morphine , Compazine and intravenous Benadryl . His blood gas at that time on 40 percent face mask was 84 , 42 , 7.48 . His hematocrit was 28 at the time of transfer . He was still guaiac positive at that time . His mental status was improved from admission to the CCU . The patient did well on the floor initially with improvement in his arterial blood gases and mental status . However , on the 24th he had a massive upper GI bleed . He was taken for esophagogastroduodenoscopy by the Surgical Service after elective intubation for airway control . The clot was dense despite multiple attempts at lavage . There was no lesion noted in the stomach . The pylorus was entered and the first and second portion of the duodenum were inspected and were seen to be normal . It was felt the patient 's GI bleeding was secondary to his previously known esophageal tear . He was readmitted to the Coronary Care Unit on the 25th , where initially he was stable . His aspirin was discontinued . He was continued on the intravenous Cimetidine and Carafate except that he was made NPO . He was seen in consultation by the OLH Service , who felt he was a candidate for total parenteral nutrition . On the 25th he developed progressive hypotension with evidence of further upper gastrointestinal bleeding . An electrocardiogram at that time showed a right rate related right bundle and apical ST changes consistent with ischemia . Repeat endoscopy was unsuccessful because of severe bleeding despite massive lavage . Three sites of active extravasation were found , one from the gastroesophageal junction area and two from the gastric fundus . He was continued to be intubated with poor mental status . He was paralyzed for the vascular procedure . Given the multi organ system failure on the 26th the family was consulted regarding his dismal prognosis and they decided to make the patient do not resuscitate without further pressures or aggressive measures with comfort care being paramount . The patient continued to have bleeding with progressive downward deterioration of his mental status and renal failure and temperature spikes . The patient died on the 31st . ZIE M.
